name: Mushroom Biryani
history: Mushroom Biryani is a variant of the classic Indian biryani, which traditionally uses meat. This version uses mushrooms as the main ingredient, making it a popular choice among vegetarians. It's known for its rich flavors and aromatic spices.
description: Mushroom Biryani is a flavorful and aromatic rice dish made with basmati rice, mushrooms, and a blend of biryani spices. It's cooked in a layered method, where the spiced mushrooms are layered with partially cooked rice and then steamed together.

instructions.title: Prepare Rice
instructions.description: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Cook the rice until it's 70% done. Drain and set aside.

instructions.title: Cook the Mushrooms
instructions.description: Heat oil in a frying pan. Add onions and sautÃ© until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies. Stir in the mushrooms, tomatoes, mint, coriander leaves, yogurt, biryani masala, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until the mushrooms are tender.

instructions.title: Layer the Biryani
instructions.description: In a large pot, layer the cooked mushrooms and rice. Sprinkle the saffron milk over the top layer. Cover and cook on a low flame for 20 minutes.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Gently fluff the biryani before serving. Serve hot with raita or a side dish of your choice.

tips: Make sure the rice is not fully cooked when boiling, as it will cook further with the mushrooms.
Use fresh, firm mushrooms for the best texture.
variations: Add fried onions on top for added flavor.
Incorporate vegetables like peas or carrots for a more nutritious dish.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in a microwave or on a stove until hot.
presentationTips: Serve in a decorative serving dish, garnished with fresh herbs.
Pair with a variety of accompaniments like cucumber raita or papad.
